Questions.QuestionString: 1. When riveting, the distance from the edge to the rivet (land) should not be less than. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 1D.
B. 2D.
C. 4D.

Questions.QuestionString: 2. To replace one 1/8 inch rivet. (Level 1)
Answers: A. three 1/16 inch rivets would be required.
B. two 1/16 inch rivets would be required.
C. four 1/16 inch rivets would be required.

Questions.QuestionString: 3. How would you use a Pacific T5 tensiometer?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Use correct chart and correct riser.
B. Use a standard riser and use the chart to correct for different sized cables.
C. Use a load meter to apply the correct load.

Questions.QuestionString: 4. What is the purpose of an aileron balance cable?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Allows for hands off flying.
B. Equalizes control cable tension.
C. Relieves pilot loads.

Questions.QuestionString: 5. How would you inspect a cable for fraying?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Run your fingers the full length of the cable.
B. Operate the controls and feel for stiffness.
C. Run a rag the full length of the cable.

Questions.QuestionString: 6. When manufacturing aircraft control cables, the cable can be cut by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. using a hacksaw with the cable under tension.
B. using an oxy-acetylene torch.
C. using a chisel on a flat metal surface.

Questions.QuestionString: 7. The check for a cable pulling out of a swaged fitting is by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. seeing that the cable is still past the safety holes in the swage.
B. looking for a shiny surface on the cable near the fitting.
C. seeing that there are no broken wires near the fitting.

Questions.QuestionString: 8. A 'Reel' used to hold an aircraft cable in storage should have a minimum diameter of. (Level 1)
Answers: A. at least 25 times that of the cable diameter.
B. at least 50 times that of the cable.
C. at least 40 times that of the cable diameter.

Questions.QuestionString:
9. Large control cables (45 to 120 cwt) may have tension loads that can break the locking wire or lease
lock nuts. How is this overcome?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. The cable is kept slightly slack.
B. Duplicating the number of cables to cut down on individual tensile loads.

C. A tube is fitted over the turnbuckle assembly and drilled to take up to 3 bolts, to prevent independent
rotation of any part.

Questions.QuestionString: 10. To correctly tension cables it can help. (Level 1)
Answers: A. to use a cable with turnbuckles at least every eight feet.
B. to take up initial slack by additional pulleys.
C. to have control surface locks in to support weight and adjust turnbuckles equally.

Questions.QuestionString: 11. A cable is replaced. (Level 1)
Answers: A. when a shiny portion is found.
B. when each strand is worn to limits.
C. if a chemical spillage is suspected.

Answers: A. 1/3 minimum breaking strain.
B. 2/3 minimum breaking strain.
C. 50% minimum breaking strain.

Questions.QuestionString:
13. If treated rivets have not been used within the prescribed time they can be re-treated. What is the
maximum number of times that they can be heat-treated?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. If no more in Stores, as many times as required.
B. Twice only.
C. Three times.

Questions.QuestionString: 14. The best way to check control cables for broken wires is to. (Level 1)
Answers: A. run a rag along the cable in both directions.
B. examine them visually.
C. increase the tension and check with a magnifying glass.

Questions.QuestionString: 15. If the turnbuckles in a control system are tightened excessively the result will be. (Level 1)
Answers: A. the cable will break.
B. the cables will vibrate excessively and cause failure of controls.

B. it will not stretch after fitting in an aircraft.
C. it will not break after fitting in an aircraft.

B. attempting to pass a hardened pin probe through the inspection hole.

B. To allow trapped air to escape.

C. to ensure that the turnbuckle is in safety.

Questions.QuestionString: 26. When checking cable tensions you are looking for. (Level 2)

Answers: A. not lubed or washed because they are lubed at manufacture.
B. washed in solvent before fitting.
C. lubricated before fitting.

Questions.QuestionString: 253. When drilling out a rivet, use a drill. (Level 3)
Answers: A. larger than the hole.
B. same size as the hole.
C. smaller than the hole.

Questions.QuestionString:
254. When riveting two dissimilar sheets of metal together the joint should be protected with. (Level
3)
Answers: A. jointing compound.
B. paint.
C. grease.

256. What type of rivet would you use when there is access to only one side of the work?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Blind.
B. Pop.
C. Hilok.

Questions.QuestionString: 257. Hoses are normally pressure tested to. (Level 1)
Answers: A. maximum working pressure.
B. 2 times maximum working pressure.
C. 1½ times maximum working pressure.

Questions.QuestionString: 258. Torque loading is carried out to provide. (Level 3)
Answers: A. as tight a joint as possible.
B. sufficient clamping without over-stressing.
C. flexibility.

Questions.QuestionString: 259. What is generally the best procedure to use when removing a solid shank rivet?. (Level 3)
Answers:
A. Drill through the manufactured head and shank with a drill one size smaller than the rivet and remove
the rivet with a punch.

B. Drill through the manufactured head and shank with a shank size drill and remove the rivet with a
punch.

C. Drill to the base of the manufactured rivet head with a drill one size smaller than the rivet shank and
remove the rivet with a punch.

Questions.QuestionString: 260. What action is taken with a common circlip removed from a component?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. It is replaced with a new item on assembly.
B. It is checked for springiness.
C. It is examined for distortion.

Questions.QuestionString: 261. The maximum bolt diameter for which a 1/16 split pin may be used is. (Level 3)
262. Why is a shouldered stud used?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. To provide a rigid assembly.
B. To decrease weight without loss of strength.
C. As a replacement for a damaged stud.

Questions.QuestionString: 263. A thread insert is removed by. (Level 3)
Answers: A. once fitted, a thread insert must not be removed.
B. using a drill the major diameter of the thread insert.
C. a special drill provided by the thread insert manufacturer.

Questions.QuestionString: 264. When fitting Rivnuts into position, how are they secured and prevented from rotating?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Locknut at the rear.
B. A locating key.
C. Peened.

Questions.QuestionString: 265. Hi-loks are installed with the. (Level 3)
Answers: A. thread and shank not lubricated.
B. shank lubricated when fitting.
C. thread lubricated when fitting.

Questions.QuestionString: 266. Immediately after carrying out an insulation check, which of the following applies?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. A continuity check must be carried out before switching on the circuit for the first time.

B. The readings observed and the atmospheric conditions at the time should be noted and compared to
previous readings.
C. The observed readings should be noted and an independent check carried out by another engineer.

Questions.QuestionString:
267. An Insulation test is carried out on a group of cables and a low reading obtained. What action
would you take?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. A low reading would be expected because the cables are in parallel.
B. Change or renew all the cables involved in the test.
C. Break the circuit down and carry out further checks.

Questions.QuestionString: 268. A fluid line marker with a skull & crossbones is. (Level 1)
Answers: A. fluid line carries toilet waste.
B. warning symbol.
C. radioactive symbol.

Questions.QuestionString: 269. BITE systems to be used on the ground only are deactivated by. (Level 3)
Answers: A. on take off.
B. the parking break.
C. by the undercarriage retraction.

Questions.QuestionString:
270. After the normal function test of an individual circuit has been completed and the circuit switched
off. (Level 3)
Answers: A. a second function test must be carried out to verify the first.

B. the fuse should be removed and the circuit again switched on to check the isolation of the circuit
concerned.
C. a duplicate check must be carried out in accordance with AWN 3.

Questions.QuestionString:
271. A millivolt drop check is to be carried out on a heavy duty relay. The Millivoltmeter would be
connected to the relay. (Level 3)
Answers: A. when contacts closed and power is on.
B. when contacts open and power off.
C. when contacts are open and power is on.

Questions.QuestionString: 272. Electrical cables installed on aircraft. What is used to indicate a fault?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Bonding test.
B. Continuity test.
C. Resistance test.

Questions.QuestionString: 273. When checking resistance of a cable to the starter motor what test is carried out?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. Millivolt drop test.
B. Safety Ohmmeter.
C. Time Domain Reflectometer.

Questions.QuestionString: 274. When inspecting an aircraft after a lightning strike, you should observe. (Level 1)
Answers: A. entry damage.
B. all signs of burning.
C. entry and exit damage.

Questions.QuestionString: 275. To ensure protection against HIRF affecting audio and navigation aids. (Level 1)
Answers: A. ensure that all audio and navigation equipment is adequately screened.
B. inspect and check all bonding leads to ensure their serviceability and replace if defective.
C. ensure that the correct number of static wicks are fitted.

Questions.QuestionString: 276. Which of the following is a preventive process against HIRF?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Monitoring HIRF on the communication system.
B. Visual inspections.
C. Periodically checking aircraft bonding.

Questions.QuestionString: 277. How do you prevent aquaplaning during landing?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Reduce flare.
B. Use reverse thrust.
C. Put flaps up.

Questions.QuestionString: 278. Skin wrinkling on the lower surface of a wing is caused by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. hogging.
B. tension.
C. sagging.

Questions.QuestionString: 279. The international marking for a water injection pipeline is a series of. (Level 1)
Answers: A. chevrons.
B. squares.
C. dots.

Questions.QuestionString: 280. After a report of flight through heavy turbulence, you would. (Level 1)
Answers: A. check the aircraft symmetry.
B. carry out a major overhaul.
C. not carry out any checks.

Questions.QuestionString: 281. After a heavy landing you should check. (Level 1)
Answers: A. engine compressor shaft alignment.
B. engine thrust alignment.
C. engine module alignment.

Questions.QuestionString: 282. A lightning strike on an aircraft would show. (Level 1)
Answers: A. the entry and exit point.
B. the entry point only.
C. the exit point only.

Questions.QuestionString:
283. When an engine is not in direct electrical contact with its mounting, how should it be bonded?.
(Level 1)
Answers: A. With at least one primary conductor.
B. With at least two primary conductors on one side of the engine.
C. With at least two primary conductors, one each side of the engine.

Questions.QuestionString: 284. On a composite aircraft, large items are bonded. (Level 1)
Answers: A. by use of large copper strips.
B. Don't need to be bonded because they are made of an insulating material.
C. by primary bonding leads attached to a cage.

Questions.QuestionString: 285. HIRF interference occurs when. (Level 2)
Answers: A. in use on mid frequencies.
B. in use on low frequencies.
C. in use on all frequencies.

Questions.QuestionString: 286. Non metallic parts of the aircraft. (Level 2)
Answers: A. do not require to be bonded because they are non conductive.
B. must be bonded by bonding leads.
C. must be bonded by application of conductive paint.

Questions.QuestionString:
287. Whenever possible a functional test should be carried out on an aircraft using which power
supply?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. The aircraft battery.
B. The aircraft generators.
C. An external supply.

Questions.QuestionString: 288. How many primary bonding conductors are required on an engine?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. 1 only.
B. 2 on one side.
C. 1 on each side.

Questions.QuestionString: 289. What is the primary purpose of bonding of metallic parts of an aircraft?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. To provide a return path for electrical two-wire system.
B. To prevent high potential differences between metallic parts from building up.
C. To prevent lightening strikes.

Questions.QuestionString: 290. The international marking for a fire protection pipe line is a series of. (Level 1)
Answers: A. circles.
B. squares.
C. diamonds.

Questions.QuestionString:
291. In order to maintain HIRF protection, bonding checks between airframe and electrical
components carrying voltages greater than 50V RMS or dc should not exceed. (Level 2)
Answers: A. 0.05 ohm.
B. 1 ohm.
C. 1 M ohm.

Questions.QuestionString:
292. Ribbon cables affected by mutual impedance and current loop leakage should be protected by.
(Level 2)
Answers: A. earthing each alternate conductor to separate points.
B. connecting all conductors to a common earth.
C. shielding each individual conductor.

Questions.QuestionString:
293. An aircraft with under-wing mounted engines has a heavy landing, where would you expect to see

Answers: A. Bottom skin caused by engine inertia.
B. Top skin only.

Answers: A. Corrosion on bonding leads.
B. Broken or missing static wicks.
C. Unserviceable radio filters.

Answers: A. To carry the static discharge current to the conducting nose wheel.
B. To carry lightening discharge current should the need arise.
C. To maintain the airframe at the same potential throughout.

Questions.QuestionString: 296. When an aircraft has been struck by lightning. (Level 2)
Answers: A. control surface bearings and hinges should be checked for stiffness in operation.

B. control surface freedom of movement need not be checked provided skin punctures are less than 3/16
inch diameter.
C. control surface freedom of movement need not be checked providing the bonding is undamaged.

Questions.QuestionString: 297. On an aircraft which has had a heavy landing, on the lower wing you may see. (Level 2)
Answers: A. sagging.
B. hogging.
C. wrinkling.

Questions.QuestionString: 298. After a reported lightning strike. (Level 2)
Answers: A. the flight controls should be checked for full and free movement before the next flight.

B. the flight controls need to be checked for full and free movement only if a bonding lead to one of the
control surfaces is found to be burned or broken.
C. the aircraft and its systems must have a major overhaul before the next flight.

Answers: A. must be displayed on all flights.
B. must be displayed in the cabin only if they are legible.

301. To prevent corrosion where aluminium alloy pipelines are supported by rubber cleats, the pipe

A. the procedures which must be complied with before an aircraft can be given a Certificate of
Airworthiness in the Transport Category (Passenger).

Questions.QuestionString: 304. An aircraft should carry at least the following number of spare fuses:. (Level 1)

Answers: A. in a folder with the operators name on the cover.

306. After a mandatory inspection has been carried out by a Licensed Engineer, what is issued. (Level

A. Appropriate Type Rated Licensed Aircraft Engineers must each certify the parts appropriate to their

Answers: A. of a legal nature in all sections and is therefore mandatory.

323. The maximum distance between end fittings to which a straight hose assembly is to be connected

Answers: A. contain information of a mandatory nature.
B. contain approved inspection schedules.

Answers: A. specify the minimum qualifications for aircrew and engineers.

Questions.QuestionString:

Questions.QuestionString: 362. Vital point inspections. (Level 2)

B. low carbon alloy steel with high strength requirements.
C. high carbon alloy steel with low strength requirements.

Questions.QuestionString: 375. A wear check on a cylinder head valve spring should include. (Level 2)
Answers: A. length under load.
B. diameter and length.
C. length off-load.

Questions.QuestionString: 376. Material used for springs is. (Level 2)
Answers: A. High carbon or alloy steel with low working stresses.
B. Low carbon steel or alloy steel with high working stresses.
C. Low carbon steel or alloy steel with low working stresses.

Questions.QuestionString: 377. Needle roller bearings. (Level 1)
Answers: A. are susceptible to brinelling.
B. can accept a small amount of misalignment.
C. are designed to carry axial loads.

Questions.QuestionString: 378. When rotating a ball bearing by hand, a regular click indicates. (Level 1)
Answers: A. damage to the balls.
B. intergranular corrosion in the outer ring.
C. a cracked ring.

Questions.QuestionString: 379. Brinelling of a wheel bearing could be caused by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. rotation of the outer race in the wheel housing.
B. heavy landing.
C. overheating of the brakes.

Questions.QuestionString: 380. Brinelling of a bearing is. (Level 1)
Answers: A. bluing of the bearing due to overheating.
B. shallow smooth depressions caused by the rollers being forced against the cup, due to overtorquing.
C. indentations in the race surface caused by continual static vibration.

Questions.QuestionString: 381. A tapered roller bearing is designed to take. (Level 1)
Answers: A. radial loads only.
B. both radial and axial loads.
C. axial loads only.

Questions.QuestionString: 382. In British rivets (solid) what is the length grading unit?. (Level 1)
383. Small indentations in the race of a ball bearing indicate. (Level 1)
Answers: A. overtorquing.
B. corrosion.
C. brinelling.

Questions.QuestionString: 384. When fitting a ball bearing to a shaft it should be carefully positioned using. (Level 1)
Answers: A. a steel drift with light blows.
B. a copper or aluminium tube drift.
C. a soft steel or brass tube drift.

Questions.QuestionString: 385. Graphite prevents seizure and conducts heat. It is normally used in. (Level 1)
Answers: A. lithium based greases.
B. sodium based greases.
C. copper based greases.

Questions.QuestionString: 386. False Brinelling of a bearing is. (Level 1)
Answers: A. movement of the outer ring relative to its housing.
B. indentations on the race-way due to load transferred through the bearing when static.
C. a scoring of the race-way surfaces due to ball or roller skidding.

Questions.QuestionString: 387. On completion of assembly the bearing housing. (Level 1)
Answers: A. should be examined for end float.
B. packed fully with grease.
C. lightly packed with grease.

Questions.QuestionString: 388. When checking a ball bearing for corrosion and foreign matter. (Level 2)
Answers: A. rotate at operational speed and check for roughness.
B. make a strip down inspection.
C. oscillate and rotate slowly to listen for roughness.

Questions.QuestionString: 389. What type of load is a journal load?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Radial.
B. Axial.
C. Centrifugal.

Questions.QuestionString:
390. Bearings to be cleaned for further examination should be wiped free of all grease on outer
surfaces with the aid of dry compressed air for cages and rolling parts. The bearings should then be
soaked in. (Level 2)
Answers: A. M.E.K.
B. lead free gasoline.
C. white spirit.

Questions.QuestionString: 391. After cleaning a bearing should be dried with. (Level 2)
Answers: A. left in free air to dry naturally.
B. clean, warm, dry compressed air.
C. lint free rags.

Questions.QuestionString: 392. Thrust bearings transmit. (Level 2)
Answers: A. thrust loads, thus limiting axial movement.
B. radial loads, thus limiting axial movement.
C. thrust loads, thus limiting radial movement.

Questions.QuestionString:
393. If the thickness of a single sheet of material, about to be joined by riveting was 1/16 of an inch
thick what would be the approximate diameter of the rivets to be used?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. 1/16 inch.
B. 3/16 inch.
C. 1/8 inch.

Questions.QuestionString: 394. Chipping of a ball bearing indicates. (Level 2)
Answers: A. brinelling.
B. chattering.
C. spalling.

Questions.QuestionString: 395. A Hardy Spicer coupling has what type of bearings?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Ball Bearings.
B. Needle bearings.
C. Plain bearings.

Questions.QuestionString: 396. Graphite greases are used for. (Level 2)
Answers: A. medium temperature applications.
B. high temperature applications.
C. low temperature applications.

Questions.QuestionString:
397. If during an engine overhaul, ball or roller bearings are found to have magnetised but otherwise
have no defects, they. (Level 2)
Answers: A. are in an acceptable service condition.
B. must be degaussed before use.
C. cannot be used again.

Questions.QuestionString:
398. Ball and roller bearings are made from a combination of low carbon steel and a percentage of.
(Level 2)
Answers: A. Chromium.
B. Nickel.
C. Nickel chrome.

Questions.QuestionString: 399. On inspection a bearing is found to have distortion, what action should be taken?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Reject bearing.
B. No action required. Some distortion is normal.
C. Blend out distortion and re-grease bearing.

Questions.QuestionString:
400. On inspection a bearing is found to show signs of overheating, what action should be taken?.
(Level 2)
Answers: A. Reject bearing.
B. No action required. Some overheating is normal.
C. clean up bearing and repack with grease.

Questions.QuestionString: 401. When a bearing has 2 parts and the inner ring and outer ring is installed. (Level 2)
Answers: A. neither of the practices are allowed.
B. the inner ring can be removed from its inner shaft for cleaning.
C. the outer ring can be removed from its housing for inspection.

Questions.QuestionString: 402. A chain removed for routine inspection, it. (Level 1)
Answers: A. does not need proof loading.
B. must be proof loaded to 50%.
C. must be proof loaded to 150%.

Questions.QuestionString: 403. An aircraft control chain is connected using. (Level 1)
Answers: A. nuts and bolts.
B. quick release pins.
C. a split link and spring clip.

Questions.QuestionString: 404. Regarding riveting, which of the following is correct?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Both of the above are correct.

B. The length of a countersunk rivet (flush head) is measured from the end of the rivet to the top of the
countersunk head.

C. The length of a round head or flat head is measured from the end of the rivet to underside of rivet
head.

Questions.QuestionString: 405. If a control chain can be lifted clear of a tooth, it should be. (Level 1)
Answers: A. rejected as unserviceable.
B. removed and an elongation check carried out.
C. cleaned, re-tensioned and inspected after a period of time.

Questions.QuestionString: 406. To check a chain for articulation. (Level 1)
Answers: A. it should be run over the finger through 180° and checked for smoothness and kinks.
B. move each link individually and check for tightness.
C. lay on a flat surface and check for kinks.

Questions.QuestionString:
407. How do you remove a tight link from a chain which is to be used on an aircraft control system?.
(Level 1)
Answers: A. Dismantle, inspect, rectify and re-assemble the chain.
B. If the chain has a tight link, the chain has to be removed from service.
C. You may be able to remove the tight link by applying a light tap with a hammer.

Questions.QuestionString: 408. The initial lubricant on a new chain. (Level 1)
Answers: A. must be replaced with grade altitude grease.
B. should be removed and replaced with the approved oil.
C. should not be removed.

Questions.QuestionString: 409. Control chains should be fitted in an aircraft. (Level 1)
Answers: A. with the minimum of slack in the chain.
B. so that the chain can be removed easily.
C. with as much slack as possible to allow for contraction.

Questions.QuestionString: 410. Backlash is a type of wear associated with. (Level 1)
Answers: A. gears.
B. rivets.
C. bearings.

Questions.QuestionString: 411. After a chain has been cleaned in paraffin it should be. (Level 1)
Answers: A. hung up to drip dry.
B. dried in hot air.
C. washed in soapy water then hung to drip dry.

Questions.QuestionString: 412. What fraction of the minimum breaking load should be the proof load for a chain?. (Level 1)
413. If corrosion is found on a chain. (Level 2)
Answers: A. replace the chain.
B. clean off the corrosion and if acceptable re-fit the chain.
C. lubricate the chain.

Questions.QuestionString: 414. The three principle dimensions specified for a chain is the diameter of the rollers and. (Level 2)
Answers: A. pitch and chain length.
B. the pitch and width between the inner plates.
C. the pitch and width across the outside of the plates.

Questions.QuestionString:
415. When riveting, a certain clearance must exist between the rivet and the hole in which it is fitted,
to allow for shank expansion. If the clearance is too large, what could be the result?. (Level 1)
Answers: A. Indentations by rivet head on the material.
B. Separation of the sheets may occur.
C. Sheet may tend to buckle.

Questions.QuestionString: 416. The distance between the centres of the rollers of a chain is called. (Level 2)
Answers: A. pitch.
B. crest.
C. length.

Questions.QuestionString:
417. Which of the following formulas should be used to calculate the percentage extension of an
aircraft control chain? Note: M = Measured length under load in inches X = Number of pitches
measured P = Pitch of chain in inches. (Level 2)
418. The maximum allowable extension of a chain assembly over a nominal length is. (Level 2)
419. A feather key locates a gear on a shaft and permits. (Level 2)
Answers: A. a positive drive with the gear firmly locked.
B. a positive and strong drive transmission.
C. a positive drive and axial movement.

Questions.QuestionString: 420. A chain is removed by. (Level 2)
Answers: A. nuts and bolts.
B. spring clips.
C. removing chain links on an endless chain.

Questions.QuestionString:
421. The box unit in a Teleflex control run which is not suitable for heavily loaded controls is called.
(Level 2)
Answers: A. Double entry.
B. Single entry.
C. Straight lead.

Questions.QuestionString: 422. How do you check a chain for elongation?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Hang chain up, check sight line and measure.
B. Adjust the end fittings.
C. Lay flat on a table, apply tensile load and measure.

Questions.QuestionString: 423. Proof testing after cable installation is. (Level 1)
Answers: A. sometimes required.
B. not required.
C. always required.

Questions.QuestionString: 424. A control cable that has been contaminated with acid should be. (Level 1)
Answers: A. cleaned.
B. rejected.
C. cleaned, inspected, and reinspected after a period of time.

Questions.QuestionString: 425. A balance cable is installed in a control system to. (Level 1)
Answers: A. allow the aircraft to be flown 'hands off'.
B. correct for wing heaviness.
C. enable the cable to be tensioned.
